turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I've got to work...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Do you want me to go...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: No, no, I'm just...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Why don't you get some rest?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I've got to work.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You can't work if you can't think. You get in bed.  It's all right. I'll stay here with you.  It's all right.  Come on...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You're going to stay here...?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Do you think it's my fault?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Isn't there something you...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: That's not the question.  It's over.  Do you think that it's my fault?  If I'd...if I'd...I never should have taken it.  There was no way that I was going to win.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You're talking like a drunk.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: That's what I am.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: And it's over...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Well, then what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I...do you want me to leave?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You do what you want.  You want to leave...You want to go kill yourself?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You want me to tell you it's your fault?  It probably is.  What are you going to do about it?   I thought it's not over till the jury comes in.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Who told you that?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You told me so.  Maybe you'd get some sympathy.  You came to the wrong place.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: And what makes you so tough?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Maybe I'll tell you later.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Is there going to be a later...?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Not if you don't grow up...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: If I don't 'grow up...'

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You're like a kid, you're coming in here like it's Saturday night, you want me to say that you've got a fever -- you don't have to go to school...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You, you don't under...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Oh, yes, I do, Joe.  Believe me. You say you're going to lose.  Is it my fault?  Listen!  The damned case doesn't start until tomorrow and already it's over for you!

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: It's over!

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What is your wife's picture doing by the side of your...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What is that to you...?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What would you like it to be to me...?  I, I, I can't invest in failure.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Joe...  Joe...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Stop pressuring me...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: You're pressuring yourself...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: No...no...

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yes.   We've all got to let go.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Is it over?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I don't have a goddamned idea.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: I have to talk to you.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Call the A.M.A.  to Laura) ...I can't talk now.  ...tell them you're Dr. Somebody...you have to find this nurse...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Dr. Gruber.

turns.speaker: MAID
turns.text: Dr. Gruber's not in.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I had an appointment at his office, I think I must have got it wrong. We had a meeting...

turns.speaker: MAID
turns.text: He's not in, Sir.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Where is he?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I...please.  My wife...my wife's prescription has run out.  If I can call him...

turns.speaker: MAID
turns.text: Dr. Halpern's taking all his...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: No, no, no.  I have to talk to him.  If I can only call him..

turns.speaker: MAID
turns.text: He's...you can't reach him, Sir. He's in the, on some island in the Caribbean, they don't have a phone.   He'll be back in a week...  If you'd like Dr. Halpern's number...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Hi, Mickey ...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What the hell do you think you're doing ...?  What's going on here ...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Uh ...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Fuck you.  I got a call today from Sally Doneghy ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... now who is that ...?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ... You're 'sposed to be in court in ten days and she's telling me you haven't even met with them ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Sally Doneghy, now who is that?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: One lousy letter eighteen months ago. . . .I try to throw a fuckin' case your way ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... hey, I don't need your charity ...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ... I get these people to trust you --they're coming here tomorrow by the way --I get this expert doctor to talk to you.  I'm doing all your fuckin' legwork -- and it's eighteen months.  You're 'sposed to be in court.  I bet you haven't even seen the file.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I have to talk to you.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Come on.  Let's get a drink.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Don't touch anything.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Are you out of your mind...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...I'm going to need your help...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You need my help...?  You need a goddamn keeper...are you telling me that you turned down two-hundred- ten grand?    Huh...?  Are you nuts?  Eh?  Are you nuts. What are you going to do, bring her back to life?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm going to help her.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: To do what...?  To do what, for chrissake...?   To help her to do what?  She's dead...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: They killed her.  And they're trying to buy it...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: That's the point, you stupid fuck. Let them buy it.  We let them buy the case.  That's what I took it for.  You let this drop -- we'll go up to New Hampshire, kill some fuckin' deer...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Mick.  Mick.  Mick...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You -- Listen:  you said to me, `if not now, when...'

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I know what I said but not now. You won it.  Franky.  You won it. When they give you the money, that means that you won.  We don't want to go to court -- is this getting to you...?  You know who the attorney is for the Archdiocese, Eddie Concannon.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...he's a good man...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ...he's a good man...?  He's the Prince of Fuckin' Darkness...he'll have people in there testifying that the broad is well -- they saw her Tuesday on a surfboard at Hyannis...don't fuck with this case.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...I have to stand up for her...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Frank, but not now.  Frank.  You're trying to wipe out some old business.  But not now.  I understand.  But you go call 'em back.  You call the Bishop back.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I have to try this case.  I have to do it, Mick.  I've got to stand up for that girl.  I need your help.    Mick, will you help me...?    Will you help me...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: We've got her sister.  Testifies she had a meal one hour before she was admitted to the hospital. This is the point.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You got the admittance form says patient ate nine hours prior to admittance.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Admittance form is wrong.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Forget it.  You can't prove it. Sister's testimony is no good. Jury knows we win she gets the cash.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I've got my Dr. Gruber, says her heart condition means they gave her the wrong anaesthetic anyway, plus she came in complaining of stomach pains...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ...Gruber's not bad.GALVIN Not bad...?  This guy's Dr. Kildare, the jury's going to love him, Mick...  And you calm down, all right?  Their guy, Towler's, the author of the book,  'Methodology and Practice, Anesthesiology.'  ...and they got depositions from the nurses, everybody in the operating room, the scrub-nurse...'All these guys are God.  I saw them walk on water...'

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: They had an obstetrical nurse in there.  We got a deposition from the obstetrical nurse?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: 'Mary Rooney, forty-nine.  Lives in Arlington, still working at the hospital.'  Can you get out tomorrow?  How come she isn't speaking up.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Okay now.  Cases:  Smith versus State of Michigan.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Brindisi versus Electric Boat.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You got a good memory, Franky.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I had a good teacher.  McLean versus Urban Transport...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Jimmy?  Bushmills.   Lookit, do me a favor.  I'll buy you a drink tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Yeah?  And what are you going to do tonight?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm going to get laid.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Been a long time, huh...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm getting it back.  Don't worry about me, Mick.  I'm fine.  D'you find the obstetric nurse?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Mary Rooney.  She won't talk to me.  I tried her at the hospital. I'm going to try her back at home. Read this.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: So what?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: So what...?  The best is yet to come.  Check the TV Guide.  They got our Dr. Towler on a panel on GBH on Friday: 'The Healing Hand. The Experts Speak.'

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: They still have to take it to a jury.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What I'm saying, they're getting some help.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: So what do you want me to do? Concannon's going to try the case his way, I'm going to try it mine. You want me to go wee wee wee all the time because he's got some flack, got stories in the newspaper. I'm going to win this case.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: John:  gimme a cuesta-ray.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Oh shit, what's today?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Today is Tuesday.  What?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I've got to go see Gruber.    What's the best cigars you have?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Give 'em a box of Macanudos.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Mickey:  I'm supposed to meet somebody at O'Rourke's, I can't make it.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What happened, Joey...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I can't talk now.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: D'you meet with Dr. Gruber...?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Yeah?  How's our new witness?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: D'you find the obstetric nurse?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: She's workin' the late shift at the Hospital.  She's at home now, I'm going over there to talk to...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Gimme the address.  I'm gonna go. We're going to need her.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: How are you holding up?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm swell.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: And all we've got is a witch doctor!

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Okay.  What do you do when you don't have a witness?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: You use their witness.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I think we tried that.  The case is over.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Are you with me...are you awake...?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Yeah.  I'm awake.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Rooney's protecting someone.  Who is she protecting?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: The Doctors.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: She's protecting the Doctors she'd be up there on the stand...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Read me what she said.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: `You guys are a bunch of whores...uh...loyalty...you don't care who gets hurt...you don't have any loyalty...'

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ...one of the other nurses?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Who?  They're all testifying. Everybody who was in the O.R.'s going to take the stand.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: All right.  Who wasn't in the O.R.?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What difference can that make...? All right...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Uh...the admitting nurse...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: What did she do?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: She didn't do anything.  She took the patient's history and signed the charts.  'K.C.'  'Kathy Costello...'

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: The 'History'...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: How old are you, how many children ... when did you last eat ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: We don't have anything from the Nurse Association?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: The broad has disappeared...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: The Hospital...?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ...yeah...good...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...you need some old forms that she had...somebody's dying...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ...four years ago...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Hello.  This is Mr. Dorchester in Records.  We're looking for Kathy Costello...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I need a cigarette!  She left my office four years ago, we're looking for a chart...  I need a cigarette...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What the hell are you doing here?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: We got to talk.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What are you doing in New York...?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Come on, we'll get a cup of coffee...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: I talked to Johnnie White at the Bar Association.   The broad used to work for one of Concannon's partners in New York awhile ago.   She wanted to move to Boston.    How badly did she hurt us, Joe?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: We got a mistrial, you know.  Joe -- did you hear what I said...?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I don't want a mistrial.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm ... Mrs. Doneghy?  I'm Frank Galvin ... why didn't you go in?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: It's locked.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: It's locked?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: It's not a good case.  It's a very good case.  A healthy young woman goes into the hospital to deliver her third child, she's given the wrong anaesthetic ...

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: ... we, we love her, Dick and me ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... I'm sure you do ...

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: But what can we do?  She don't know who's visiting her ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... I know.  I went ...

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: ... You saw her?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes.  Yes, I have.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: You know how beautiful she was?   Her husband left her, and he took her kids .... They, they, they'd let you die in there.  They don't care.  Nobody cares.  The Patriot Home, the Chronic Care ... in Arlington ...?  They'd take her in.  Perpetual care.  They'd take her.  Fifty thousand dollars they want.  An endowment.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... fifty thousand dollars?

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: I don't want to leave her.  Dick ...the, the ... and Father Laughlin, he said that it was God's will ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... I understand ...

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: My doctor told me that I got to move out West ... that's when we filed in court.  We didn't want to sue ...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... I understand ...

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: ... But Dick, he's looking for two years in Tucson ... and they called him  up and said to come out. He's a good man.  He's only trying to do what's right.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: He saw her at the Northern Care...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ... and I have inquiries out to doctors, experts in the field ... there is, of course, a problem getting a doctor to testify that another doctor's negligent ...

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: We just can't do it anymore.   This is our chance to get away.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I'm going to see you get that chance.

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: What does it mean?    I...I mean we, you have other tactics...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: We, yes.  Yes.  They, they present their side, and I get the same chance.  To cross-examine... to... to...

turns.speaker: SALLY
turns.text: Are we going to win?    We have, you know, other tactics, though...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I spoke to her, and everything is all right.

turns.speaker: ROONEY
turns.text: I, what are you talking about?  I talked to her this morning, and she said...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: She told me.

turns.speaker: ROONEY
turns.text: She did?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I just saw her.

turns.speaker: ROONEY
turns.text: In New York?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ROONEY
turns.text: You saw Kat in New York...   ...or is she in town? Is she in town...?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Hi.  How are you doing?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I've been meaning to come in a long time.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: You live in the neighborhood?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Uh-huh.  My nephew's going to be staying with us in a few months, so I stopped by.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: How old is he?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Four.  You're great with these kids.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You're really...  You, are you the one they told me was the nurse?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Who told you that?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Mrs...

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Mrs. Simmonds.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I used to be a nurse.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: That's a wonderful profession.  My daughter-in-law's a nurse.  What did you do, stop?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Kathy Price...

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You were the Admitting Nurse at St. Catherine Laboure Hospital on May twelfth, nineteen seventy-six, the night Deborah Ann Kaye was admitted...

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: These are your initials, 'K.C.'?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Kathy Costello.  That's my maiden name.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: D'you ask the patient when did she last eat?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What did she say?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: She said she had a full meal one hour before coming to the hospital.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: One hour.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: And did you write the numeral `one' down on the record, standing for one hour?

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: A single hour.

turns.speaker: KATHY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Another, Frank . . . ?

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...everybody.  Mike says, `Pat, you mean to tell me for a buck you get a free lunch and a beer, and then you go in the back and get laid?'  `That's correct.'  Mike says, `Pat.  Have you been in this bar ?'  Pat says, `No, but my sister has ...'   Everyone.  Buy yourself one too.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: I want to buy you a drink.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Thanks, Franky.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Well, well, well.  Huh?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: It's a long road that has no turning.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: That's for sure, Frank.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Dr. Towler...

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: You have a record of what happened in the operating room...

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: Yes, that's correct.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...there are notations every thirty seconds...

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...of the procedures...

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: Yes, the roving nurse...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: But those notations stop...  ...four-and-one-half minutes after Deborah Ann Kaye's...

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: We, we were rather busy...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Four-and-one-half minutes after her heart stopped.    And they resume seven minutes...

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: As I've said we had some more...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: ...they start again three minutes earlier...

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: We had rather more important things on our mind than taking notes.   We were trying to restore her...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What happened in those three...

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: ...we were trying to restore her heartbeat.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: What happened in those three minutes...?

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: We'd gone to 'Code Blue,' we were administering electro...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Why did it take that long to get her heartbeat...

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: Brain damage could have been...it didn't necessarily take nine minutes, it could have been caused in two...

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Wait, wait, wait, you're saying that her brain damage could have been caused by her being deprived of oxygen for two minutes...?

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GALVIN
turns.text: Huh.  And why is that?

turns.speaker: TOWLER
turns.text: Because she was anemic.  It's right there on her chart. Her brain was getting less oxygen anyway...

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Franky can't make it.  He had an appointment he forgot, he's going to see you later.  I'm Mickey Morrissey, we're supposed to get to know each other.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: How'm I doing so far?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: So far you're great.  You got a cigarette?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Stearns, Harrington, you know who that is?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Should I?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: A huge law firm.  Okay?  They put him in the firm, he's married, everything's superb.  Franky, he's starting to talk like he comes from Dorsetshire, some fuckin' place, 'You must drop by with Pat and me...'  Okay...?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: ...and he's making a billion dollars every minute working for Stearns, Harrington, and he bought a dog, and everything is rosy.   Then Mr. Stearns, he tried to fix a case.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: The Big Boy did...?

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: That Frank was working on.  Yeah. He thought Franky needed some help, so they bribed a juror.  So Franky finds out.  He comes to me in tears. He thinks that anybody who knows what a 'spinnaker' is got to be a saint.  I told him ' Franky, wake up.  These people are sharks. What do you think they got so rich from?  Doing good?'  He can't be comforted.  He tells the boys at Stearns and Harrington they've disappointed him, he's going to the Judge to rat them out.

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Huh.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Before he can get there here comes this Federal Marshal, and Franky's indicted for Jury tampering, they throw him in jail, he's gonna be disbarred, his life is over.   Jimmy, gimme another drink.    How are you?

turns.speaker: LAURA
turns.text: Me, too.

turns.speaker: MICKEY
turns.text: Okay.  Now, so he's in jail.  He, finally, he gets to see the light, he calls up Harrington, he says he thinks he made a mistake.  As if by magic, charges against him are dropped, he's released from jail.   P.S.  He's fired from the firm, his wife divorces him, he turns to drink  and mopes around three and a half years.   You like that story?

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: Doctor, how long is it going to take you to pull him out of this?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: It is hard to say. Six months, at least. Perhaps a year. It depends to a certain extent on him.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: He won't talk.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No. We have ways of digging out knowledge. But it takes longer. He is suffering from acute melancholia, together with a guilt complex. He blames himself for what happened to the woman. And we know little of the background.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: I can give you one thing: he was in love with her.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Ah? That complicates the problem.

turns.speaker: MIDGE
turns.text: I'll give you another complication: he still is.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: How'd you get into the shipbuilding business, Gavin?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: I married into it.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Interesting business.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: No, to be honest, I find it dull.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: You don't have to do it for a living.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: No. But one assumes obligations. My wife's family is all gone; someone has to look after her interest. Her father's partner runs the company yard in the East -- Baltimore -- so I decided as long as I had to work at it, I'd come back here. I've always liked it here.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: How long have you been back?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Almost a year.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: And you like it.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: San Francisco's changed. The things a that spell San Francisco to me are disappearing fast.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Like all this.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: I'd like to have lived here then. The color and excitement... the power...  the freedom.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Shouldn't you be sitting down?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, I'm all right.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: I was sorry to read about that thing in the papers.  And you've quit the force.  A permanent physical disability?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, Acrophobia isn't a crippling thing. It just means I can't climb steep stairs or go to high places, like the bar at the Top-of-the-Mark. But --  -- there are plenty of street-level bars In this town.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Would you like a drink now?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No... no, thanks. A bit early in the day for spirits.  Well, I guess that about covers everything, doesn't it? I never married; I don't see much of the "old college gang"; I'm a retired detective -- and you're in the shipbuilding business.  What's on your mind, Gavin?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Not what you think. We're very happily married.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Then?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: I'm afraid some harm may come to her.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: From whom?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Someone dead.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Scottie, do you believe that someone out of the past, someone dead, can enter and take possession of a living being?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: If I told you I believe that his happened to my wife, what would you say?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I'd say you'd better take her to the nearest psychiatrist, psychologist, neurologist, psychoanalyst, or plain family doctor. And have him check you both.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Then you're of no use to me. I'm sorry I wasted your time. Thank you for coming in, Scottie.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I didn't mean to be that rough.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: No, it sounds idiotic, I know. And you're still the hard-headed Scot, aren't you? Always were. Do you think I'm making it up?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: I'm not making it up. I wouldn't know how. She'll be talking to me about something, nothing at all, and suddenly the words fade into silence and a cloud comes into her eyes and they go blank... and she is somewhere else, away from me... someone I don't know. I call to her and she doesn't hear. And then with a long sigh she is back, and looks at me brightly, and doesn't know she's been away... can't tell me where... or why...

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: How often does this happen?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: More and more in the past few weeks. And she wanders. God knows where she wanders. I followed her one day.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Where'd she go?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Watched her come out of the apartment, someone I didn't know... walking in a different way... holding her head in a way I didn't know; and get into her car, and drive out to...  Golden Gate Park. Five miles. She sat on a bench at the edge of the lake and stared across the water to the old pillars that stand an the far shore, the Portals of the Past. Sat there a long time, not moving... and I had to leave, to got to the office. That evening, when I came home, I asked what she'd done all day. She said she'd driven to Golden Gate Park and sat by the lake. That's all.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: The speedometer of her car showed she had driven 94 miles that day. Where did she go?  I have to know, Scottie. Where she goes and what she does, before I got involved with doctors.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Have you talked to the doctors at all?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Yes, but carefully. I'd want to know more before committing her to that kind of care.  Scottie --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I can get you a firm of private eyes to follow her for you. They're dependable, good boys --

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: I want you.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: It's not my line.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Scottie, I need a friend!  Someone I can trust! I'm in a panic about this!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: How can I see her, to know her?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: We're going to an opening at the opera tonight. We'll dine at Ernie's first.  Which is easier?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Ernie's.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: All right.  You won't know what to look for at first, Scottie. Even I, who know her so well, cannot tell, sometimes, when the change has begun. She looks so lovely and normal...

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: You've done well, Scottie. You're good at your job.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: That's Carlotta Valdes.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: There are things you didn't tell me.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: I didn't know where she was going to lead you.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: But you knew about this.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Oh, yes. You noticed the way she does her hair.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Something else. My wife, Madeleine, has several pieces of jewelry that belonged to Carlotta. She inherited them. Never wore them, they were too old-fashioned... until now. Now, when she is alone, she gets them out and looks at them handles them gently, curiously... puts them on and stares at herself in the mirror... and goes into that other world... is someone else again.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Carlotta Valdes was what: your wife's grandmother?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Great-grandmother. The child who was taken from her whose loss drove Carlotta mad and to her death - was Madeleine's grandmother.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Well, that explains it. Anyone could develop an obsession for the past, with a background like that.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: But she doesn't know, about her background.  She never heard of Carlotta Valdes.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Knows nothing of a grave out at Mission Dolores, or an old house an Eddy Street, or a portrait at the Palace of the Legion of Honor?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: And when she goes to those places...

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: She is not my wife.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: How do you know all these things she doesn't know?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Her mother told me most of then before she died. I dug out the rest for myself, here.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Why did she never tell her daughter?

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: Natural fear. Her grandmother went insane and took her own life. And the blood is in Madeleine.  Scottie, I ask you to watch her closely.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: He had no right to say that. It was my responsibility. You didn't know her. I shouldn't have got you involved.

turns.speaker: ELSTER
turns.text: No, there's nothing you have to say to me. I'm getting out, Scottie. For good. I can't stay here. I'm winding up her affairs, and mine. I'm going to get as far away as I can. Probably Europe. And I'll probably never come back.  Good-bye, Scottie. If there's anything I can do for you before I go...

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: ELSTER'S VOICE
turns.text: Scottie, what happened? She's not home, yet.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, she's all right. She's still here. But I'll get her home soon.

turns.speaker: ELSTER'S VOICE
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: She... went into the Bay.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: ELSTER'S VOICE
turns.text: Did she hurt herself?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No. She's in fine shape. Nothing to worry about. But she doesn't know. You understand that. She doesn't know what she did.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Could I ask you a couple of questions?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: What for? Who are you?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: My name is John Ferguson, and --

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Is this some kind of Gallup Poll, or something?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, there are just a few things I want to ask you, and --

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Do you live here in the hotel?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, I happened to see you come in, and I thought --

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: 0h, I thought so! A pick-up!  Well, you've got a nerve, following me right into the hotel and up to my room! You beat it! Go on! Beat it!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, please! I Just want to talk to you!

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Listen, I'm going to yell in a minute!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I'm not going to hurt you! I promise! Please!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Just let me talk to you.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: What about?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: You.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I've heard that one before, too. I remind you of someone you used to be madly in love with, but she ditched you for another guy, and you've been carrying the torch ever since, and then you saw me and something clicked.  Huh!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: You're not far wrong.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Well, it's not going to work. So you'd better go.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Let me come in.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I warn you, I can yell awfully loud.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: You won't have to.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Well... you don't look very much like Jack the Ripper...

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: What do you want to know?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Your name. And --

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Judy Barton.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Who you are --

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Just a girl, I work at Magnin's --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: -- and how you happen to be living here.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: It's a place to live, that's all.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: But you haven't lived here long.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: About three years.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, a year ago! Where did you live a year ago!!?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I told you! Right here!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: But before! Where did you live before!?!

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Salina, Kansas!

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Listen, what is this? What do you want?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I want to know who you are.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I told you! My name is Judy Barton! I come from Salina Kansas. I work at Magnin's! I live here! My gosh, do I have to prove it?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Will you have dinner with me?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Well, I feel I owe you something for all this...

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: No, you don't owe me anything.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Then will you for me?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Dinner... and what else?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Just dinner.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Because I remind you of her?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Because I'd like to have dinner with you.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Well... I've been on blind dates before... Matter of fact, to be honest, I've been picked up before.  Okay.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I'll get my car and be back in half an hour.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Oh, no! Give me time to change and get fixed up!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: An hour?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Mmm.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Thank you again. Good-night.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Can I see you tomorrow?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Tomorrow night? Well --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Tomorrow morning.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Tomorrow m -- but I have to go to work. I've got a job.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Don't go.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: And what will I live on? My oil wells in Texas?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I'll take care of you.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Oh, Well, thank very much. But no thanks.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, Judy, you don't understand.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Oh, I understand, all right. I've been understanding since I was seventeen. And the next step is, as long as you're going to see me tomorrow, why don't you stay the night.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: No? Then what?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I just want to see you as much as I can!

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: As friends? We'd just see a lot of each other as friends, and you'd "take care of me"?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Why?  Because I remind you of someone?  That's not very complimentary.  And nothing would... happen...

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: That's not very complimentary, either.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, Judy, I'm not going to move! Please! Stay in the chair!

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Why?!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Please! And don't look at me.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Will you, Judy?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I suppose I could phone the store in the morning, and say I'm sick.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I like that one.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, there. There's a good one. Do you like that?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Yes --

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Okay. Now we're going to buy you some clothes.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Honest?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: There's Ransohoff's. Nothing but the best. Come on.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: But Scottie, you don't have to!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I want to! Come on!

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: But I like that one, Scottie.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, it's not right.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Scottie, what are you doing?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: I'm trying to buy you a suit.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: But I loved the second one she wore. And this one --  -- is beautiful.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: They're none of them right.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: But why?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: You want me to dress like her?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Judy, I just want you to look nice. And I know what kind of suit would look well on you.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Ah, no!!! I don't want to be dressed like someone dead!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Judy --

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: It's a horrible idea! Is that what I'm here for? To make you feel that you're with someone that's dead?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Judy, it can't make much difference to you. I just want to see how you'd look and I know it won't be the same, but --

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: No, I don't want any clothes! I don't want anything! I want to get out of here!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Judy, you've got to do this for me! Please!

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I don't like it!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: We'll take it! Will it fit?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I wish you'd leave me alone. I want to go away.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: You can.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: No, you wouldn't let me.  And I don't want to go...

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Judy, I want to tell you: these few days have been the first happy days I've had in a year.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I know. Because I remind you of her. The one that's dead. And not even that, very much.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, it's you too, Judy. Something in you.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: You don't even want to touch me.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Yes. Yes, I do.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: The color of your hair...

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Ah, no!

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Judy, please it can't matter to you...

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: The trouble is, I'm gone now. For you. And I can't do anything about it. I want you to love me. If I let you change me, will that do it? If I do what you tell me, will you love me?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: All right. Then I'll do it. Because I don't care about me anymore. I just want you to love me.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: It should be back from your face -- with a bun at the neck. I told them. I told you.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: We tried it. It didn't suit me.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Where shall we go for dinner?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Wherever you'd like...

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Ernie's?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: You've got a thing about Ernie's, haven't you?

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Well, after all, it's "our place."

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Mmmm.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Is that the best you can do?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: Come here.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Oh, no. You'll muss me.

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: That's what I had in mind.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: Too late. I've got my face on.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I'm suddenly hungry. Would you rather go somewhere else?

turns.speaker: SCOTTIE
turns.text: No, Ernie's is fine.

turns.speaker: JUDY
turns.text: I'm going to have one of those big beautiful steaks.  And... let's see... to start...
